summary: The U.S. District Court for the Central District of California today entered a final judgment against Facebook, Inc. and two entities it controls for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in San Diego, California, alleges that, in 2014 and 2015, Mikel Knight and two companies he controlled, 1203 Entertainment, LLC and 1203, engaged in a fraudulent scheme to create and disseminate false and misleading information about Knight and his companies.  According to the complaint, Knight allegedly created a fake Facebook page called “Families Against Mikel” in which he claimed that he was the "publisher or speaker” of user-generated content.  In reality, the complaint alleges, Knight was not the publisher or speaker of the content on the pages, but rather, in Knight’s words, “a person or entity that is responsible, in whole or in part, for the creation or development of any content provided by another information content provider.”  The complaint further alleges that the defendants used the names of third parties who were using the defendants’ names to create the fake Facebook pages.  As alleged, the defendants were not liable for the content of the posts, and the defendants could not show a probability of prevailing on any of the charges.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC’s complaint, Facebook has agreed to settle the case by consenting to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins it from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, and orders it to pay disgorgement and prejudgment interest, with the amount of any civil monetary penalty to be determined by the court at a later date.   The settlement is subject to court approval.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-17-17. Â On June 5, 2014, the court granted a request for a temporary restraining order and entered an order temporarily restraining the defendants from disseminating or disseminating any third-party material on the internet without the court's knowledge or consent.  On June 6, 2015, a federal district court in Los Angeles granted a motion for an injunction against further violations of the anti-SLAPP provisions of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17(a) ofÂ the Securities Act of 1933, and ordered the defendants to pay a civil penalty of $10,000.Â The court also denied the motion for a preliminary injunction against future violations of Section 230 of the
